description.narrative: The development intervention's intended outcome read as follows: "Ensuring viability and sustainable implementation of the Three step Reintegration Program for Persons Released from Prison or Given the Alternative Sentences".

Convictus Ukraine has applied to Sida for funding of 2 070 000 SEK (corresponds to USD 224 974) to carry out the "Support to Convictus Phase Out" Project in Ukraine during the period 01.11.2015-31.12.2016. The intervention aims at ensuring further adoption and sustainability of three step reintegration programme for persons on probation or returning from detention facilities by: 1) facilitation of effective operation of the "Three step reintegration programme for persons returning from detention facilities or given alternative sentences; 2) ensuring the sustainability of the reintegration programme through support from the local government and/or establishing the probation facilities.
The proposed intervention builds upon the previous successful cooperation with Convictus on establishing the Reintegration Model and establishment of Halfway House. Current project is designed to allow Convictus Ukraine to ensure sustainability of the model and its further adoption into the national legislative framework.
The intervention's total budget is 2 300 000 SEK (including SEK 230 000 as contingencies), out of which SEK 1 013 211 is the funding for Convictus Ukraine and the rest SEK 1 056 779 is funding for the social institution "Halfway House". Sida undertakes to finance a maximum of 2 300 000 SEK, out of which 230 000 SEK (coresponds to USD 24 997) is contingencies. Convictus Ukraine shall separately apply for the contingencies in the event of unexpected and unplanned costs within the project and obtain Sida’s written approval.
Convictus Ukraina har ansökt om 2 300 000 SEK (motsvarande 249 971 USD) för att utföra projektet ” Support to Convictus Phase Out" i Ukraina under perioden 01.11.2015-31.12.2016.
Bidragets syfte är att säkerställa att tre stegs återanpassningsprogram för personer som är dömda till skyddstillsyn eller som återvänder från fängelser, vidare antas och är hållbart. Detta ska ske genom att: 1) underlätta en effektiv drift av "Tre stegs återanpassningsprogram för personer som återvänder från förvarsanläggningar eller ges alternativa straff; 2) säkerställa återanpassningsprogrammets hållbarhet genom stöd från den lokala regeringen och/eller upprättande av övervakningsmekanismer.
Den föreslagna åtgärden bygger på tidigare framgångsrika samarbetet med Convictus gällande upprättande av en återanpassningsmodell och etablering av Halfway House. Det aktuella projektet är utformat på ett sätt som ger Convictus Ukraina möjlighet att säkerställa modellens hållbarhet och dess vidare antagande i den nationella lagstiftningen.
Bidragets totala budget är 2 300 000 SEK (USD 249 971), varav USD 110 119 är finansiering av Convictus Ukraina och resterande USD 114 854 är avsedda för finansiering av den sociala institutionen "Halfway House".
Sida förbinder sig att finansiera högst 2 300 000 kronor, varav 230 000 kronor (motsvarande USD 24 997) är oförutsedda kostnader. Vid behov skall Convictus Ukraina skriftligen ansöka om oförutsedda kostnader och få Sidas skriftliga godkännande.
The support for Convictus and its Half Way House is required to allow for national replication of the model by the relevant central authorities. This is the one year project phase out.

description.narrative: The Program was successfully implemented by the Halfway House Center and since April 2017 it was taken over by Kharkiv Regional Municipal Entity "Crisis Social Center for Women”. Women participating in the programme were successfully rehabilitated and some were also employed. In total, the following indicators were achieved:- relapse rate – 6.6%- employment rate – 64%- family relationships restored – 84%- documents recovered – 56%- work skills and qualifications obtained – 18%. During the programme period the Half Way House: - conducted a successful advocacy campaign aimed at changing the social policy priorities of Kharkiv Regional State Administration (funding the operations of the Kharkiv Regional Crisis Social Center for Women was included in the regional government priorities);- strengthened cooperation with rayon and city social protection departments and Centers of Social Services for Families, Children and Youth of Kharkiv oblast aimed at improving the interaction and providing services to the target groups of the municipal entity. Thus, in the first half of 2017, a number of joint activities were implemented by the Center and the Social Protection Department of the Kharkiv Regional State Administration;- strengthened partnerships with governmental and non-governmental institutions; - Center's employees attended a series of trainings on advocacy, gender equality, response to human trafficking and domestic violence to improve the quality of services for target groups and encourage partnerships between government institutions and NGOs. Half Way House under Convictus support conducted a serious of fund raising activities with a purpose to sustain and maintain the Center after the project's end. Some were partially successful, however the biggest challenge was to collect enough funds for the Centre's sustainable operation. Unfortunately, the most majority of women - clients of the Centre do not poses skills and knowledge and their trainings cost a lot. Moreover, local employers still feel resistant of employing women who were imprisoned. The biggest programme's achievement was the decision of Kharkiv Regional Council to establish the Kharkiv Regional Municipal Entity "Crisis Social Center for Women” in the Halfway House Center for Social Adaptation in February 2017. The Crisis Social Center for Women will be funded from the regional budget and will serve two main purposes: - to provide shelter for women who have suffered from domestic and gender-based violence and / or trafficking;- to facilitate social adaptation of women released from prison. In total, 167 women passed the Half Way House Reintegration Programme (27 of them are from the temporarily occupied territories of Donetsk and Lugansk oblasts).
